channel.title: Culadasa's audio archive
channel.description:
Culadasa (John Yates, Ph.D.) is a meditation master with over four decades of experience in the Tibetan and Theravadin Buddhist traditions. He taught physiology and neuroscience for many years at the Universities of Calgary and British Columbia. Later, he worked at the forefront of healthcare education and therapeutic massage, serving as the founding director of the West Coast College of Massage Therapy. Culadasa retired from academia in 1996, moving with his wife into an old Apache stronghold in the Arizona wilderness, where they deepened their spiritual practice together. He currently leads the Dharma Treasure Buddhist Sangha in Tucson, Arizona and holds retreats across the United States.
Culadasa’s book, The Mind Illuminated, is the first comprehensive guide to Buddhist meditation for a Western audience. It combines age-old teachings with the latest research in cognitive psychology and neuroscience, providing meditators with step-by-step guidance for every stage of the path – from your very first sit, all the way to mastery of the deepest states of peace and insight. This is the clear, friendly, and in-depth meditation manual that people have been waiting for.

channel.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates

The Mind Illuminated podcast from Culadasa (John Yates, Ph.D.) combines age-old teachings with the latest research in cognitive psychology and neuroscience, providing meditators with step-by-step guidance for every stage of the path – from your very first sit, all the way to mastery of the deepest states of peace and insight.
Culadasa is a meditation master with over four decades of experience in the Tibetan and Theravadin Buddhist traditions. He taught physiology and neuroscience for many years at the Universities of Calgary and British Columbia. Later, he worked at the forefront of healthcare education and therapeutic massage, serving as the founding director of the West Coast College of Massage Therapy. Culadasa retired from academia in 1996, moving with his wife into an old Apache stronghold in the Arizona wilderness, where they deepened their spiritual practice together. He currently leads the Dharma Treasure Buddhist Sangha in Tucson, Arizona and holds retreats across the United States.

item.title: Sit, Breath, Wake Up! Meditation #1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Building a Powerful Meditation Practice.
How does one succeed in meditation? No matter what style or method of meditation you practice, whether you’re just a beginner or have been practicing for years, if you ever experience agitation, distraction and mind-wandering in your meditation or find yourself getting drowsy and dull, these retreat recordings are for you. They include a series of guided meditations, through which you can learn specific techniques for overcoming these and other obstacles that stand in the way of becoming an accomplished meditator. Culadasa guides you through a variety of other practices, including Cultivating Joy, Loving Kindness, Finding the Still-point, and Realizing the Witness. Interspersed among the guided meditations, which have been a popular part of past teaching retreats, are question and answer sessions. These teachings explore what it means to be mindful, both on the cushion and in daily life, and how mindfulness is cultivated.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: What the Buddha Taught, Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handouts: http://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/20130322--what-the-buddha-thought--handout.pdf http://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/20130322--what-the-buddha-thought--slides.pdf
What the Buddha taught, in his own words, was “Suffering, and the end of suffering.” He had no intention of establishing a religion, nor of teaching philosophy, cosmology, and metaphysics, and he said so repeatedly. As it turns out, though, the end of suffering involves a kind of wisdom that encompasses both the nature of human experience, and the ultimate nature of reality. And the end of suffering, the nature of human experience, and the ultimate nature of reality are key issues in religion, philosophy, cosmology and metaphysics. Thus there was no way for him to guide people towards the end of suffering without broaching topics associated with all those domains. As a result, beginning even before he died, people have been turning his wisdom teachings into religions, and have used them as the foundation for a variety of philosophies, cosmologies, and metaphysical descriptions of reality.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

As it turns out, though, the end of suffering involves a kind of wisdom that encompasses both the nature of human experience, and the ultimate nature of reality. And the end of suffering, the nature of human experience, and the ultimate nature of reality are key issues in religion, philosophy, cosmology and metaphysics. Thus there was no way for him to guide people towards the end of suffering without broaching topics associated with all those domains. As a result, beginning even before he died, people have been turning his wisdom teachings into religions, and have used them as the foundation for a variety of philosophies, cosmologies, and metaphysical descriptions of reality. item.title: The Path to Awakening in Daily Life, Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handout: http://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/Awakening%20in%20Daily%20Life%20-%20Handout.pdf
The Suttas tell us that the path to Awakening is open to all – men or women, old or young, lay or monastic. The Buddha once named 21 eminent lay disciples who had become Arahats (AN 6.119 & 120). We don’t know at what point in his 45 year teaching career this Sutta was spoken and so it is quite possible, and even likely, that by the end of the Buddha’s life there were many more lay Arahats than are spoken of here. There can be no question that Awakening is possible for Buddhist laypersons.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa

item.title: The Magic of Mindfulness, Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handout: https://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/Magic%20of%20Mindfulness%20Handout.pdf
When the mindfulness of a samurai swordsman fails, he loses his life. When we lose mindfulness in daily life, something similar happens. We become so entangled in our own thoughts and emotions that we lose contact with the bigger picture. Our perspective narrows, we lose our way, and we end up doing and saying things that bring suffering and regret. On the other hand, being mindful allows us to recognize our options, choose our responses, and take control over the direction of our lives. It also gives us the power to alter our past conditioning and become the person we want to be. And, most importantly, mindfulness also leads to Insight, Wisdom and Awakening.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates

item.title: Meditation and Insight, Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handouts: http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/Meditation-and-Insight-I.pdf http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/Meditation-and-Insight-II.pdf http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/Meditation-and-Insight-III.pdf http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/Insight_Slides-October2012.pdf
In this teaching retreat, Culadasa focuses on Insight, what it is, how it is achieved through meditation, and dispels the mystery surrounding it. The Pali word for Insight is Vipassana, which can also be translated as “special seeing” or “seeing the essence.” The Insight he is referring to is “Supramundane” Insight into the true nature of reality, not just ordinary insight. Insight into things as they really are leads to true Wisdom, then suffering ends and happiness follows. This is the ultimate goal of meditation. He talks about the “Progressive Stages of Insight,” which describes the specific pattern of how Insight develops. Understanding this pattern will speed your progress. He also talks about the difference between Insight and Insight experiences. Understanding the nature of Insight helps you recognize Insight experiences when they happen. All Insight experiences can potentially lead to actual Insight, but too often they go unrecognized, because the mind is not properly prepared. He talks about the “Progressive Stages of Insight,” which describes the specific pattern of how Insight develops. Understanding this pattern will speed your progress. He also talks about the difference between Insight and Insight experiences. Understanding the nature of Insight helps you recognize Insight experiences when they happen. All Insight experiences can potentially lead to actual Insight, but too often they go unrecognized, because the mind is not properly prepared. Understanding how to properly prepare your mind to produce and internalize the truth these experiences offer will make your meditation much more effective. item.title: Joy & Meditation, Part 1, Introduction - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handout: http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/Meditation%20and%20Joy%20Handout.pdf
Joy plays a very special role in Buddhist meditation practice. The spontaneous arising of Joy marks an important stage in the progress of every meditator’s practice. Meditative Joy, often referred to as rapture, is one of the Seven Factors of Enlightenment taught by the Buddha. It is also a factor of deep Meditative Absorptions, and is distinguished from happiness or bliss, with which it is easily confused. Culadasa explores what Joy really is, how it differs from happiness, and what makes it so important to the spiritual life. Learn where Joy comes from, how it can be cultivated on the cushion, and how discovering the Joy inherent in work and family life can improve the quality of your meditation practice.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa

Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: What Is Enlightenment? Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handout: http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/What%20Is%20Enlightenment%20Handout.pdf
The purpose of the Eastern meditation traditions is to bring us to a completely new way of being, known as Enlightenment, Awakening, or Liberation. What exactly does this mean? And how does this relate to us, living as we do in a 21st century technological society confronted with problems that were unheard of even a generation ago. Culadasa leads this weekend teaching where the methods of meditation practice and their immediate benefits are fit into a larger perspective. He then takes participants beyond the meditative practices to examine their ultimate goal, a goal that often seems hidden somewhere beyond the immediate horizon. The Buddha’s definition of Awakening is explored along with how being an Awakened being manifested both in his own life and in the lives of others who have followed this Path to its end. Here we explore the relevance of this 2500 year old Path to Awakening to ourselves, the practical attainability of its goals, and to come to an understanding of how meditation, concentration, awareness, mindfulness, and Insight that we have been cultivating as a part of our daily practices are woven together to make up this Path.
Buy Culadasa's books on Amazon: http://amazon.com/author/culadasa
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/
item.itunes:subtitle: Pdf handout: http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content…
item.description: Pdf handout: http://dharmatreasure.org/wp-content/uploads/What%20Is%20Enlightenment%20Handout.pdf The purpose of the Eastern meditation traditions is to bring us to a completely new way of being, known as Enlightenment, Awakening, or Liberation. What exactly does this mean? And how does this relate to us, living as we do in a 21st century technological society confronted with problems that were unheard of even a generation ago. The Buddha’s definition of Awakening is explored along with how being an Awakened being manifested both in his own life and in the lives of others who have followed this Path to its end. Here we explore the relevance of this 2500 year old Path to Awakening to ourselves, the practical attainability of its goals, and to come to an understanding of how meditation, concentration, awareness, mindfulness, and Insight that we have been cultivating as a part of our daily practices are woven together to make up this Path.

item.title: When the Buddhadharma Came to the West, Part 1 - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Pdf handouts: https://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/BuddhadharmaWestPartI.pdf & http://s3.amazonaws.com/dharmatreasure/BuddhadharmaWestPartsIIandIII.pdf
Buddhadharma means “the Truth of the Awakened one”. It refers to the unique set of teachings set forth by the historical person we know as “the Buddha”. “Buddhism is a Western word coined to refer to the many different eastern religions that are based on the Buddhadharma. The Buddha didn’t start a religion, nor did he promote any existing religion. But every Asian culture in which his teachings have become established has incorporated the Dharma into preexisting religious frameworks, thus making it into a religion. This is good news for us, because it means that Buddhist spirituality doesn’t require anyone to abandon his or her current religion, even those who count themselves as agnostic or atheist. Indeed, many Buddhist meditators today don’t identify their religion as Buddhism.

The Jhanas: The Original Practice of Mindfulness and Insight. Culadasa explains what Jhana is and why it is so important. There is a profound relationship between Jhana practice, Mindfulness, and the cultivation of Insight. How Jhana practice relates to the goal of achieving Insight and Awakening is described. Through a series of guided meditations, participants have an opportunity to learn about and experience Jhana first hand.

item.title: What is Karma? - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Culadasa gives the historical background of Sanskrit word “karma” and explains the Buddha’s presentation of karma. How “karma” creates our world and how in ultimate reality the “self” does not exist independently is also talked about. What we need to do to create a better world is explored.

item.title: Will Power and Achievement - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
"Olympic athletes achieve tremendous things by apparent sheer force of will. This seems in contrast to the practices that we are learning here. Can you comment on this?" Culadasa comments on the observation that Olympic athletes encourage and exemplify extreme efforts at achieving worldly goals. The benefits to society are considered and contrasted to efforts that are aimed at helping all living beings end suffering.

item.title: Piti (Joy) - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
What should one do when Piti arises? Piti is a very specific joy associated with a state of deep tranquillity. It is often translated with the English words “joy” or “rapture” and is distinguished from the longer-lasting meditative “pleasure” or “happiness” (Pali, Sanrkit: sukha) that arises along with piti. Culadasa discusses how it arises and what to do when it does.

Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: How to Develop Introspective Awareness - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
What is the method for developing Introspective Awareness? Culadasa defines introspective awareness as knowing 1) what is going on in the mind, 2) Why it is going on, and 3) If it is supposed to be going on. Introspective awareness is a subclass of mindful awareness. He further explains in detail how it is developed to a student at the 4th meditation stage.

item.title: The Awakening Process - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
How does “awakening” occur? Culadasa continues with his discussion of path and insight by describing ways Awakening can occur. This leads him to explain more about possible paths to the goal and give a deeper description of emptiness.

item.title: How Does Insight Fit into the Meditation Systems? - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
How does Vipassana fit into the stages of meditation?
Culadasa explains the path of Insight from its beginnings to the ultimate Awakening. This is a continuation of the question on what happens after the nine levels. He goes on to give more details on the experience of Awakening.
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/
item.itunes:subtitle: How does Vipassana fit into the stages of meditat…
item.description: How does Vipassana fit into the stages of meditation? Culadasa explains the path of Insight from its beginnings to the ultimate Awakening. This is a continuation of the question on what happens after the nine levels. He goes on to give more details on the experience of Awakening. item.title: Levels After the First Nine Meditation Stages - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
What happens after the nine stages of meditation?
Master Culadasa describes the levels of development after the meditation stages that lead to shamata. Specifically he describes the 7 stages (seven purifications) that start at shamata and end with Awakening. The last seven purifications are further divided into 16 knowledges. Finally, he demonstrates the correlation between the five path system with the stages of purification system.
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: Can a Cessation Be an Object of Consciousness? - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
Can a “lack” (of something) be an object of the consciousness?
Culadasa explains an absence of something cannot be an object of consciousness, but a conceptualization of an absence can be. He presents a detailed view of emptiness. This question follows a question of skipping stages of the path.
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/
item.itunes:subtitle: Can a “lack” (of something) be an object of the c…

item.title: Bypassing Steps to Awakening? - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
"You have outlined a discreet number of steps in different systems of practice. Can some of these be bypassed?"
Culadasa explains more about the process of awakening. In particular how it is more pleasant to have shamata before insight. (Especially the knowledge of fear, misery and disgust.)
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: Mind Unification - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
What are the processes that are taking part in the deep mind? Culadasa discusses the complexity of the mind and the different parts that are working on separate processes. For instance, in level four of the meditation stages part of the mind can be on the meditation object while other parts of the mind are happily thinking.
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/

item.title: Changing Your Destiny - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
"How do I, as a karmically determined individual, alter the course of my destiny and move towards enlightenment?" Culadasa discusses how we exercise free will in the present moment to change our future. Old karma and the creation of new karma is explained.

Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa

item.title: Behind the Veil - Culadasa
item.itunes:author: Culadasa, Dr. John Yates
item.itunes:summary:
How can meditation help us know that we are not self-existent ourselves, just like everything out there? Culadasa discusses the process of getting behind the veil. “Everything you are doing is trying to create enough equanimty so the mind will cease for a moment its endless creation of the world.”
Follow Culadasa on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Culadasa.John.Yates
Follow Culadasa on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Culadasa
Much more at: http://DharmaTreasure.org/
